snippet: Even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away.
abstract: Syrians are cowering with additional fear as they describe a wave of lawlessness sweeping country not unlike the crime wave Iraq experienced during the conflict there; even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away; kidnapping, rare before, is now rampant; rebel leaders have been trying to fill the void; but as bloody ground battles rage throughout the city, rebel control is limited.

byline.original: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and DAMIEN CAVE
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times reported from Aleppo, and Damien Cave from Beirut, Lebanon. Hala Droubi contributed reporting from Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and Dalal Mawad and Hwaida Saad from Beirut.

lead_paragraph: Even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away.

headline.seo: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria as Its Cities Reel From War
headline.main: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria as Its Cities Reel From War
headline.print_headline: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria As Its Cities Reel From War
